div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Upon being asked by a Reader whether the verses contained in this book were true .

body.p: And is it True ? It is not True . And if it were it would n't do , For people such as me and you Who pretty nearly all day long Are doing something rather wrong . Because if things were really so , You would have perished long ago , And I would not have lived to write The noble lines that meet your sight , Nor B. T. B. survived to draw The nicest things you ever saw . H. B .

lg.l: Who ran away from his Nurse , and was eaten by a Lion .
There was a Boy whose name was Jim ;
His Friends were very good to him .
They gave him Tea , and Cakes , and Jam ,

body.p: read him Stories through and through , And even took him to the Zoo — But there it was the dreadful Fate Befell him , which I now relate .

lg.l: You know — at least you ought to know .
For I have often told you so —
To leave their Nurses in a Crowd ;
Now this was Jim 's especial Foible ,
He ran away when he was able ,
He slipped his hand and ran away !
He had n't gone a yard when —
With open Jaws , a Lion sprang ,
The Boy : beginning at his feet .
Now just imagine how it feels
When first your toes and then your heels ,
Your shins and ankles , calves and knees ,
Are slowly eaten , bit by bit .
No wonder that he shouted “ Hi ! ”
The Honest Keeper heard his cry ,
“ Ponto ! ” he ordered as he came
( For Ponto was the Lion 's name ) ,
“ Let go , Sir ! Down , Sir ! Put it down ! ”
The Lion made a sudden Stop ,
He let the Dainty Morsel drop ,
And slunk reluctant to his Cage ,
But when he bent him over Jim ,
The Lion having reached his Head ,
When Nurse informed his Parents , they
Were more Concerned than I can say :—
His Mother , as She dried her eyes ,
Said , “ Well — it gives me no surprise ,
He would not do as he was told ! ”
Bade all the children round attend
And always keep a-hold of Nurse
For fear of finding something worse .
Who chewed bits of String , and was early cut off in Dreadful Agonies .

His Parents stood about his Bed

Are all the Human Frame requires ... ”
With that the Wretched Child expires .
Who told Lies , and was Burned to Death .
It made one Gasp and Stretch one 's Eyes ;
Her Aunt , who , from her Earliest Youth ,
Had kept a Strict Regard for Truth ,
The effort very nearly killed her ,
And would have done so , had not She
For once , towards the Close of Day ,
And finding she was left alone ,
Within an hour the Gallant Band
Were pouring in on every hand ,
From Putney , Hackney Downs and Bow ,
With Courage high and Hearts a-glow
They galloped , roaring through the Town ,
Inspired by British Cheers and Loud
They ran their ladders through a score
Of windows on the Ball Room Floor ;
And took Peculiar Pains to Souse
The Pictures up and down the House ,
In showing them they were not needed
And even then she had to pay
To get the Men to go away !
It happened that a few Weeks later
Her Aunt was off to the Theatre
She had refused to take her Niece
To Punish her for Telling Lies .
That Night a Fire did break out —
You should have heard Matilda Shout !
You should have heard her Scream and Bawl ,
And throw the window up and call
To People passing in the Street —
Their confidence ) — but all in vain !
For every time She shouted “ Fire ! ”
And therefore when her Aunt returned ,
Matilda , and the House , were Burned .

lg.l: Who slammed Doors for Fun and Perished Miserably .

lg.l: She was not really bad at heart ,
But only rather rude and wild :
It happened that a Marble Bust
Above the Door this little Lamb
And Down it came ! It knocked her flat !
It laid her out ! She looked like that .
Her funeral Sermon ( which was long
And followed by a Sacred Song )
Mentioned her Virtues , it is true ,
But dwelt upon her Vices too ,
And showed the Dreadful End of One
Who goes and slams the door for Fun .
The children who were brought to hear
The awful Tale from far and near
They never more would slam the Door .

lg.l: The Lights went out ! The Windows broke !
The Room was filled with reeking smoke .
And in the darkness shrieks and yells
And crunching , as of broken bones ,
And dreadful shrieks , when , worst of all ,
The House itself began to fall !
It tottered , shuddering to and fro ,
Then crashed into the street below —
Which happened to be Savile Row .

lg.head: MORAL
lg.l: The moral is that little Boys
Should not be given dangerous Toys .
Who always Did what was Right , and so accumulated an Immense Fortune .
The nicest child I ever knew
He never lost his cap , or tore
In eating Bread he made no Crumbs ,
He was extremely fond of sums ,
The Parsing of a Latin Word —
He sought , when it was in his power ,
He often , at his Father 's Board ,
Would beg them , of his own accord ,
To give him , if they did not mind ,
The Greasiest Morsels they could find —
His Later Years did not belie
In Public Life he always tried
To take a judgment Broad and Wide ;
In Private , none was more than he
He rose at once in his Career ,
And long before his Fortieth Year
And built the Splendid Mansion which
Where he resides in Affluence still
